params.alt: Mindfulness Now at Birmingham Newman University
params.title: Mindfulness Now at Birmingham Newman University

params.text:
Welcome to the first week of the course!

Mindfulness is often described as "waking up" to the present moment, learning to step out of automatic pilot and fully experience what’s happening right now. But what does that actually mean, and how can it help you as a student?

This week, you’ll explore what mindfulness is, how it works, and why so many people find it helpful for reducing stress, improving focus, and navigating challenges. You’ll also get a first-hand experience of mindfulness through simple practices like mindful breathing and the body scan meditation. You will also be invited to practice bringing mindfulness to eating.

 

How this course is structured

Each week you'll find:

  • Short videos & optional readings to introduce key ideas
  • Guided mindfulness exercises to try at your own pace
  • Self-reflection prompts to deepen your understanding
  • Home practice suggestions to explore mindfulness in daily life

 

At the end of this week, you’ll find your home practice, a chance to apply what you’ve learned in small, manageable ways. There’s no right or wrong way to approach it. Just see what works for you!
Now, try it out. Watch the below video and practice mindfulness for just one minute.

params.text:
Before diving further into this course, take a moment to reflect on why you’re here. Mindfulness can mean different things to different people. Some people use it to manage stress, others to improve focus, and some simply to be more present in daily life.

Consider these questions:
🧠 What made you interested in mindfulness?
💭 Are there particular challenges or aspects of university life you hope it will help with?

There are no right or wrong answers. This is simply a chance to set your own intentions for the course. 

You may want to jot down a few thoughts in a notebook or a journal, or just take a moment to think about it. At the end of the course, it's a good idea to revisit these reflections and see if anything has changed.

metadata.title: Try it out for one minute

params.text:
Mindfulness meditation isn’t about emptying your mind, or sitting perfectly still. 

It’s simply about noticing what’s happening in the present moment. There’s no special posture required, no need to sit cross-legged, and no expectation to stay completely still.

We're inviting you to have a go at paying attention to your breathing. In this brief meditation, you’ll bring your attention to your breath, gently bringing your attention back whenever your mind wanders (which it will, that’s normal!).

Don't worry if you feel you're not doing it right - there is no one right way to meditate! Meditation is a practice, which means it's something you'll come back to again and again. 

 

Please remember to prioritise your well-being so if you feel unwell during this meditation, stop the meditation.

params.text: Chapter five of Williams, J.M.G. and Penman, D. (2011) Mindfulness: a practical guide to finding peace in a frantic world. London: Piatkus.

panels.title: Want to know more? Read this extract from Finding Peace in a Frantic World

params.text:
Coming out of automatic pilot

Jon Kabat-Zinn defines Mindfulness as "the practise of paying attention to the present moment, on purpose, non-judgementally and as if your life depends on it."

Most often, we don't pay attention to the present moment. Have you ever arrived somewhere and realised you don’t remember the journey at all? Or eaten a meal while scrolling on your phone, barely tasting it? 

That’s automatic pilot: a mode where we go through the motions without really being present.

Being on automatic pilot isn’t always bad: it helps us do routine tasks efficiently. But if we live our lives this way, we risk missing out on important moments, signals from our body, and opportunities for connection. We might not notice stress creeping in, or the small joys of everyday life, like the crunch of an apple, the warmth of sunlight, or the sound of laughter nearby​.

Mindfulness helps us step out of automatic pilot and experience life as it unfolds, moment by moment. This next exercise—the Raisin Meditation—is a great example of that.

👉 Before you start, grab a raisin (or something small you haven't eaten for a while—maybe a grape, a piece of chocolate, or a nut).

This is a chance to meditate with Mark Williams, one of the leading figures in mindfulness research, and experience how slowing down and paying attention can transform even the simplest experience.

Press play whenever you’re ready.

panels.title: Want to know more? Read Holzel's research article

params.text:
Now, we're going to try out a slightly longer meditation, the body scan.

Remember, meditation isn't about sitting perfectly still with a still and empty mind. It’s simply about noticing what’s happening in the present moment with a sense of curiosity and kindness. There’s no special posture required, no need to sit cross-legged, and no expectation to stay completely still.

The Body Scan Meditation is a way to tune into physical sensations, helping you shift out of your head and into the present moment. You don’t need to force relaxation or feel a certain way. Just notice what’s there.

The key is to let go of any pressure to get it “right”. Just get comfy (lay, sit, stand: whatever works for you) and hit the play button.

 

Remember to prioritise your wellbeing, so if you feel any discomfort, please halt the meditation.

metadata.title: Mindfuless practices: breathing and body scan

params.text:
This week’s home practice

Mindfulness works best when it becomes part of daily life, rather than just something you do once and forget about. This week, try weaving it into your routine in small, simple ways.

No pressure, just curiosity.

Pick either the mindful breathing or body scan meditation and set aside a few minutes each day to give it a go. It doesn’t have to be perfect. Just notice what happens when you take time to pause and pay attention.

panels.title: ☀️ 1. Try a short Mindfulness practice each day

params.text:
Mindfulness isn’t just about meditation, it can also be part of everyday activities. This week, choose one ordinary task to do mindfully, such as:


🍽 Eating a meal (noticing the taste, texture, and smell of your food)
🚶 Walking (feeling your feet on the ground, noticing your surroundings)
🦷 Brushing your teeth (paying attention to the sensations instead of zoning out)

panels.title: 🌿 2. Bring Mindfulness into Something You Already Do

params.text: If you’d like, take a moment to jot down a few thoughts after your practice. You could write about how the meditation felt, what you noticed, or a moment this week when you were truly present. No need for long entries, just whatever comes to mind.
That’s it! No right or wrong way to do this. Just explore and see what feels useful for you.
